comments.commentBody: I don't get that sense from the pundits. Maybe Charles Blow will surprises us with some new data sometime soon. Right now, everything I see is pretty disheartening.

Well then, you'll have no trouble understanding Geraldo Rivera's logic! Oh, and please, Stu, if you do understand, please explain it to me.

http://tinyurl.com/lxxu3ux

Wasn't the bible used to justify slavery?

(A relative nit about an article I deeply admire.)

"...our brains, thanks to some enhancement, will work like a computer"

If you understand the real limitations of digital computers/finite state machines, you must realize that getting our brains to work like computers would be a degradation, not an enhancement.

Or brains (not mine, but some of them, anyway) can do all of mathematics while no digital computer ever can.

To make our brains be as limited as a computer would be yet another colossal failure! A huge step backwards.

Well-chosen! This Brit never said a cross word on the baseball diamond.

John, I heartily believe that any newspaper crossword should be accompanied by a (non-obscure) photo of some personage who relates to the grid -- a bit of visual dash, as well as a metapuzzle to be solved after the grid is filled.

Did you patent this idea? Trademark? Servicemark??

I hope it catches on.
@Kevin - there have been enough Million Moms boycotts that we know exactly what would happen, what would be said, and who would lead it.

It's kinda humorous when people in Washington state and New Mexico argue about how roundup has or hasn't affected milkweed in the midwest. I live in rural central Missouri. I have lived in Iowa. My husband is a seed analyst for farm crops. Claiming that herbicide use has not affected the amount of milkweed available for monarchs is wishful thinking. Arguing that ethanol has had little effect is even sillier. How many acres of CRP land has been taken out of the program to feed the ethanol plants that have popped up? http://www.fsa.usda.gov/FSA/webapp?area=home&subject=copr&topic=crp

We have noticed, however, recent efforts to bring back milkweed. We have also noticed that the people who mow the right of way for the county and state sometimes mow around the milkweed.

Mostly what I have noticed is the tremendous decline, particularly the past couple of years, of monarch activity. Several years ago we had literally thousands and thousands of them overnight in the yard,draped from oak trees like blankets. This year there were hardly any.

The price of corn doesn't matter one iota unless the cost of growing it is factored in. The article does not even address what glyphosate does to the soil biota. But that's okay. Monsanto will sell you something to amend the soil after it's been depleted.

Sorry, but no - there are not ample amounts of stream banks, water ways, etc. etc. out here in corn country.  Ponds have been filled in, shelter belts have been torn out, many wildlife populations have been decimated due to lack of habitat. Pull off the Interstate when driving through central Nebraska, which runs along the barely existent Platte River, and all you will see are irrigated fields of corn, with an occasional soybean field thrown in. There are still some places in Nebraska where ground water is not as accessible, therefore the occasional pasture & stand of trees along a creek still exist, but they are few and far between.  And yes, that corn is inedible.  Really shouldn't even be fed to cattle, but that's another post.

Vanessa Hall.....For the record, I grew up in rural Illinois and I have been involved with corn and soybean farming all my life, still am. I am presently retired in New Mexico where I have a 450 tree apple orchard, which I do not spray in spite of the fact that the coddling moth takes 3/4 of the crop, because I enjoy the birds and wildlife. I am a member of the Audubon Society, The Nature Conservancy, and a regular contributor to the Sigurd Olson Environmental Institute (Northland College). I have probably planted 10,000 plus trees in my life time, and I have purchased property for the sole purpose of keeping it out of the hands of developers, for which I reap an annual benefit of paying a significant amount of property tax. The fact that I have a strong environmental background does not mean I approve of inappropriate comments about ethanol and GMOS. False statements do more damage than good.

I share the concern about the monarch butterfly and the reduction of habit in the Midwest, but I deplore the misrepresentation in this article. For example:....."Soaring demand for corn, spurred by federal requirements that gasoline be laced with corn-based ethanol, has tripled prices in a decade".......The fact is that the price of corn today is about $4.25 a bushel, while the average price in 2003 was $2.50 (please check my numbers). Has the price of corn tripled in the last decade? It is true that the price of corn was significantly higher last year do to a wide spread drought, but that had nothing to do with ethanol. It would appear that the author of the article has an axe to grind and is not averse to providing false information. It is true that a concerted effort to restore habitat should be carried out, but there is no need to attack prime farm land. Even in areas with heavy agriculture, there are ample amounts of stream banks, water ways, power line easements, road right-of-ways, wood edges, and even back yards. These are the areas where a concerted effort should be made to restore milkweed and other native plants. Unfortunately, this article smacks of ulterior motives. There is a solution if people of good will work together, but there can be no justification for blatant dishonesty.

"trumped by science" my, my, my.

My dear Mr. Zola, do yourself a favor and read some of Jacob Bronowski before you so greatly overrate science.

(I, myself, have only a scientific education and took only one philosophy course.)

What I wonder is whether the conservatives who protest that he has a right to speak out on his "religious" views would spring to his defense so quickly if he were Muslim. As a Christian, I cringe when people claim biblical justification for their intolerance--you can find a rationale for almost any act or attitude in "holy" books.
That pie on top is gorgeously crimped--just like Mom used to make.  I never got the hang of it.

The whole drone issue is so sickeningly disgusting.
Can you imagine if drones from other countries flew around America and shredded people at will?
Where is the outrage? The inhumanity is obvious.
No wonder there is so much hate and so many people seeking revenge in this world.
Would we expect the Yemeni government, or any government, to drone people to death here?  What would the American people think of that, once our own wedding parties were dying of their drones?
You live in a country so obsessed with fear, so isolated from the rest of the world, that you see enemies everywhere.  Get out there, it is a magnificent world.
Because there are people in Yemen who want to blow up the U.S. and we might want to stop them?
Has it occurred to you that the killing there by drones is making things worse, is causing more people to take up arms, whatever weapons they can, against the US?

Ms. Lisa,

Where are the data showing that drone strikes kill fewer noncombatants than rifles or other lethal means? As far as I know there are no credible public data. However, available historical data on aircraft bombings reveal extraordinarily high rates of noncombatant deaths compared to other lethal means of combat. i don't know why we would assume that drone missile strikes are any better targeted.

i think you show much to much reverence for our military and government press releases. The idea that this is just about defending ourselves seems to me to be its own special type of pious nonsense.

So you think we're insufficiently paranoid? I say we're far, far, too paranoid. We need to cease harassing airline passengers rather to start harassing train and subway passengers. And if we don't want to be killed by people from other countries, we should stop killing people in other countries ourselves.

When something happens at an airport in the US that threatens the lives of passengers, we don't blame the president; it's not his job. But, when a drone hits innocent people in another country, so many people are ready to blame him for what is really either an innocent mistake on the part of the person who pulled the trigger or something more nefarious on that person's part. Perhaps we need to look at the people who are supposed to TRAIN the shooters. Is it so impossible to imagine that, in a hate-filled country like ours, some of these MISTAKES were deliberate?

We had more than 3000 people killed in our country by terrorists, but most people seem to have forgotten this because of all the restrictive measures we face at airports nowadays. Every time we upgrade our defenses at airports we make ourselves more vulnerable. Every morning in NYC alone more than 1500 people crowd onto each of many dozens of subway and railroad trains. Not even ONE of our railroad or subway stations has even ONE baggage screening device - not even Penn or Grand Central Station has ONE baggage screening device. We are totally open for another catastrophic attack.

Instead of spending millions of dollars on drones and off-duty airline pilots who do the shooting, we should spend the money to protect our subway and rairoad stations. If it's rational to have spent money to protect our planes, it's even more raitonal to protect trains, because these targets are still leaving the barn unprotected.
I'm all in favor of upholding the Second Amendment rights of Yemeni citizens! (Tongue planted firmly in cheek)
"It remains unclear *who* the Americans were trying to kill..."

We firebombed 34 Japanese cities killing---according to the architect MacNamara over 1 million people, most woman and children and the elderly, none of whom had anything to do with Pearl Harbor.

This is your solution to dealing with handfuls of terrorists?

You're naive if you think they would stop hating us if we did otherwise. On the contrary, the hate would be the same, the pride taken in it would grow. I am totally against killing innocent people, but let's not use our perspective here - we have to stop fooling ourselves hoping that the world would love America. People never love the more powerful, it is as simple as that. Russians never understood that, so up to this day they have not recovered from their reality check.

And their children will hate us. And so it will go down to their children's children and beyond if we don't stop killing grandmother's working in the fields or people celebrating a wedding.

There is nothing ever remotely moral about killing innocent people with machines from the sky and calling it collateral damage.

That already happened, LKL.

Look up September 11, 2001. It's in the history books.

Because every drone has a pilot, and the dead don't care if the pilot lived or died after they themselves were killed.

But, LKL, suppose that tomorrow President Obama declared a policy to never again use armed drones in any circumstance?  Think through all the likely consequences -- internationally, in domestic politics,etc.  And, as you do, please keep in mind that this "horse is out of the barn" -- there's really nothing that would prevent other countries (or other actors) from developing and using armed drones (many countries already have them) short of something akin to the Non-proliferation Treaty.

To me this was just as evil as the wedding party that was bombed in Israel by Palestinians. Maybe even worse because it was preventable.

Evil is evil and we will reap what we have sown.

It is not an impossible scenario to think one day, some day, a drone will fly over our heads and land in one of our schools, hospitals, bridges or our apartment building! And it won't be Amazon delivering the books we ordered either!

I am so disappointed in President Obama over this drone issue.

The technology is available and may even be on its way to those who WILL use it against us....and why would they not use drones to wound us as we have wounded them?
My two little grand-daughters have recently been flower girls in weddings, this is a horror I can all too well imagine and my heart aches and weeps with those who had to see their innocent loved ones murdered.

Yea, I agree. in a sense it's really the Yemeni government killing these innocent people not us. And a government killing their own civilians is ample reason for regime change or at least lots of bombing

In honour of Perfesser Breedlove, I'll be thinking of her as Princess AMYGDALA.

Don't know who she is anyway, so it makes little difference.

Leapy, if you've never seen a movie with Princess AMIDALA as a character, you have lived better than many.

This I can say, however: If you want proof of the physical resemblance that at one time existed between Keira Knightly (sp?) and Natalie Portman, you'll want to find still shots from the movie where one plays AMIDALA and one plays a decoy AMIDALA.

A very worthy puzzle, a fine avatar, superb comments! One hundred cheers to all concerned.

I once again appreciate the little blue-box notes, which make sure no one misses anything other than by their own choice.

There's a little inside baseball with the use of entry word KREWE; if Mr. Steinberg is reading this, perhaps he can let us in on other grid secrets?

Flush with pride on my completion of the Google puzzle, I took the virtual DNF on this one by looking up McDill's location in TAMPA. After spending as much effort in that area as I had in the whole rest of the grid, it was just time.

Noted some interesting connections between the fine NYT puzzle and the easier but excellent Google puzzle:
1. NYT gives us LORELEI, Google had LURE
2. NYT gives us FUNGICIDE, Google had FUNGUS
3. NYT gives us Princess AMIDALA and effects technique CGI, while Google had Star Wars mastermind George LUCAS
4. NYT wants us SOLEMNER, while Google spoke to us of PROFUNDITY

Both puzzles had FUN tonight! But neither one chose to W. Chung tonight.

I have recommended almost every comment prior to mine! I also recommend doing the "Second Sunday" puzzle; it's a variety not often seen, and a great test of vocabulary. Oh, and the byline reads "Will Shortz"!! Must be done on paper.

Enjoy, all!

-- Millennial Timely Fun

I suspect that many of DD's fans share those attitudes. I admit that I have a bit of "white trash" in my DNA too, and a few of my relatives (very few, but some) would probably agree with this guy to a great extent.
Yet another reason to keep the cell phone ban on airplanes.   Being reachable all the time interferes with everyone's entertainment.
next to south africans, americans are quite beautiful within the spectrum of racism, apparently.

anyone remember 'The Ugly American' ?
Sad that they still exist.
Ignorant and insensitive.
